articles.title: Uber and Momenta will test fully driverless cars in Germany
articles.description: Uber and one of its many robotaxi partners, Momenta, will test fully driverless cars in Germany next year. The news comes as Europe continues to lag behind the US and China in the number of commercially operational robotaxi services. The companies say they will test Level 4 autonomous vehicles in Mu
articles.content: Uber and one of its many robotaxi partners , Momenta, will test fully driverless cars in Germany next year. The news comes as Europe continues to lag behind the US and China in the number of commercially operational robotaxi services. The companies say they will test Level 4 autonomous vehicles in Munich starting in 2026. (Level 4 describes fully driverless vehicles, without safety drivers, that can operate anywhere within a defined geographic area.) If everything goes according to plan in Munic
articles.author: Andrew J. Hawkins

articles.description: In December 1947, three physicists at Bell Telephone Laboratories‚ÄîJohn Bardeen, William Shockley, and Walter Brattain‚Äîbuilt a compact electronic device using thin gold wires and a piece of germanium, a material known as a semiconductor. Their invention, later named the transistor (for which they wer
articles.content: In December 1947, three physicists at Bell Telephone Laboratories‚ÄîJohn Bardeen, William Shockley, and Walter Brattain‚Äîbuilt a compact electronic device using thin gold wires and a piece of germanium, a material known as a semiconductor. Their invention, later named the transistor (for which they were awarded the Nobel Prize in 1956 ), could amplify and switch electrical signals, marking a dramatic departure from the bulky and fragile vacuum tubes that had powered electronics until then. Its inve
articles.author: Julia R. Greer

articles.content: Every year MIT Technology Review celebrates accomplished young scientists, entrepreneurs, and inventors from around the world in our Innovators Under 35 list . This year, though, the context is pointedly different: The US scientific community finds itself in an unprecedented position, with the very foundation of its work under attack . To be treated properly, they must first get diagnoses‚Äîwhich means having their genomes s
articles.content: Sneha Goenka is one of MIT Technology Review‚Äôs 2025 Innovators Under 35. Meet the rest of this year‚Äôs honorees . Up to a quarter of children entering intensive care have undiagnosed genetic conditions. To be treated properly, they must first get diagnoses‚Äîwhich means having their genomes sequenced. This process typically takes up to seven weeks. Sadly, that‚Äôs often too slow to save a critically ill child. Hospitals may soon have a faster option, thanks to a groundbreaking system built in part by
articles.author: Helen Thomson

articles.content: Anyone familiar with the AI slop on Pinterest should recognize how unnatural that hair is. I opened TikTok while visiting Germany last week and stumbled across a Vodafone ad being presented by a woman who probably doesn‚Äôt exist. The ad includes several ‚Äútells‚Äù that suggest the presenter was artificially created using generative AI ‚Äî the unnatural style and movement of her hair, the way her moles disappear, and the uncanny valley vibe of her facial expressions ‚Äî and Vodafone confirmed my suspicio

articles.title: TIL #super_method
articles.description: Consider this: def name binding . pry " #{ super } #{ last_name } " end You pry into a method and want to find out the source/location of other called methods. Usually this is easy, just method(:last_name).source or method(:last_name).source_location and voila. But what if the method calls super ? �
articles.content: Consider this: def name binding . pry " #{ super } #{ last_name } " end You pry into a method and want to find out the source/location of other called methods. Usually this is easy, just method(:last_name).source or method(:last_name).source_location and voila. But what if the method calls super ? ü§î Not to worry, #super_method to the rescue: > method(__method__).super_method.source > method(__method__).super_method.source_location
articles.author: Augusts Bautra

articles.title: Microsoft's cloud service restored after reports of cut cables in the Red Sea
articles.description: Microsoft said its Azure cloud platform has returned to normal service after an incident of cut underwater cables that played out over Saturday. The tech giant reported " undersea fiber cuts " in the Red Sea on Saturday morning, which disrupted Azure service throughout the Middle East and led to pot
articles.content: Microsoft said its Azure cloud platform has returned to normal service after an incident of cut underwater cables that played out over Saturday. The tech giant reported " undersea fiber cuts " in the Red Sea on Saturday morning, which disrupted Azure service throughout the Middle East and led to potential "increased latency" for users. Microsoft said that the latency issue was resolved by Saturday evening and was able to reroute the Azure traffic through other paths. Microsoft didn't provide
articles.author: Jackson Chen

articles.title: Network Discovery vs. Network Inventory: What‚Äôs the Difference?
articles.description: Teams often use ‚Äúnetwork discovery‚Äù and ‚Äúnetwork inventory‚Äù as if they were the same. They aren‚Äôt. Discovery finds what‚Äôs connected right now; inventory tracks those assets over time. Treat them as one and you get blind spots and audit pain. Pair them and you get a reliable map plus the context to m
articles.content: Teams often use ‚Äúnetwork discovery‚Äù and ‚Äúnetwork inventory‚Äù as if they were the same. They aren‚Äôt. Discovery finds what‚Äôs connected right now; inventory tracks those assets over time. Treat them as one and you get blind spots and audit pain. Pair them and you get a reliable map plus the context to manage it well. This guide explains what each does, how they differ, and a practical way to run both together‚Äîwithout spreadsheets or guesswork. What is Network Discovery? Network discovery is the auto
